citation.article-title: Heliobacterium chlorum, a anoxygenic brownish-green photosynthetic bacterium containing a new form of bacteriochlorophyll.

p.s: Description of Heliobacterium gen. nov., Gest and Favinger 1983.
Heliobacterium (He.li.o.bac.te'.ri.um. Gr. n. helios sun; Gr. neut. dim. n. bakterion a small rod.
Gram-negative rod-shaped cells, frequently slightly bent, ca. 1 μm wide and of variable length (7-10 μm or longer).
On complex medium agar, colonies have irregular margins due to wavy protrusions of cell masses in palisade formations, typical of gliding bacteria.
Grows photoheterotrophically over a temperature range of 20-41°C (optimum at 35-37°C); biotin required.
As cultures age, cells show a pronounced tendency to spheroplast and
Nitrogen sources: N2 or ammonium salts
Photosynthetic pigments: bacteriochlorophyll gag is the major pigment (in vivo, the main absorbancy peak is at 788 nm; relatively small peaks are also observed at 575 and 670 nm).
In addition to bacteriochlorophyll gGg, cells contain a low concentration of a neurosporene-like carotenoid.
Young cultures are brownish-green, and later become emerald-green in coloration.
Source: surface soil collected in front of Jordan Hall of Biology, Indiana University, Bloomington, Indiana.
The strain has been deposited in the American Type Culture Collection (ATCC) as number 35205.
